lesson.name: Lesson 9.8: Rewriting Quadratic Expressions in Vertex Form

page.title: 9.8.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will review the vertex form of a quadratic expression, its advantage, and its connections to the graph. You will also review how to transform expressions in factored form to standard form, and expressions in vertex form into standard form. You will then experiment with transforming the same expressions in standard form back to vertex form.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Identify the vertex of the graph of a quadratic function when the expression that defines it is written in vertex form.
  • Explain the meaning of the term "vertex form" and recognize examples of quadratic expressions written in this form.
  • When given a quadratic expression in factored form, rewrite it in standard form.
  • When given a quadratic expression in standard form, rewrite it in vertex form.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 9.8.1: The Vertex and Intercepts of a Function
  • 9.8.2: Expanding from Factored Form to Standard Form
  • 9.8.3: Converting from Standard Form to Vertex Form
    • 9.8.3: Self Check
    • 9.8.3: Additional Resources
  • 9.8.4: Rewriting Expressions in Vertex Form
    • 9.8.4: Self Check
    • 9.8.4: Additional Resources
  • 9.8.5: Different Forms of Quadratic Expressions
  • 9.8.6: Vertex Form and Coordinates of the Vertex

After that, you'll practice and review.

  • 9.8.7: Practice
  • 9.8.8: Lesson Summary

page.title: 9.8.1: The Vertex and Intercepts of a Function
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

These expressions each define the same function.

  • \(x^2+6x+8\)
  • \((x+2)(x+4)\)
  • \((x+3)^2âˆ’1\)

Without graphing or doing any calculations, determine where the following features would be on a graph that represents the function.

  1. The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex (of a graph).

Enter the \(x\)-coordinate.

Correct! The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex is -3.

The correct answer is -3. The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex is -3.


  1. The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex (of a graph).

Enter the \(y\)-coordinate.

Correct! The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex is -1.

The correct answer is -1. The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex is -1.


----------------------------------------
  1. Select both \(x\)-intercepts.

Correct! The \(x\)-intercepts are \((-2,0)\) and \((-4,0)\).

The correct answers are: \((-2,0)\), \((-4,0)\). The \(x\)-intercepts are \((-2,0)\) and \((-4,0)\).

------------------------------------

  1. The \(y\)-coordinate of the \(y\)-intercept \((0, \_\_\_\_\_)\)

Enter the \(y\)-coordinate of the \(y\)-intercept.

Correct! The \(y\)-intercept is \((0,8)\).

The correct answer is 8. The \(y\)-intercept is \((0,8)\).

page.title: 9.8.2: Expanding from Factored Form to Standard Form
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Recall learning how to identify and factor perfect square trinomials in Unit 6. Here are some perfect squares in factored and standard forms, and an expression showing how the two forms are related.

Study the first few examples in rows 1 and 2. Create a similar table to the one modeled below. Copy the table (or use a copy provided by your teacher) and then complete the missing numbers in rows 3â€“6 in the rest of the table.

Row

Factored form

  

Standard form

1

\((x+4)^2\)

\((1x)^2+2(1x)(4)+4^2\)

\(x^2+8x+16\)

2

\((2x+5)^2\)

\((2x)^2+2(2x)(5)+5^2\)

\(4x^2+20x+25\)

3

\((3x-4)^2\)

\((3x)^2+2(\_\_\_\;x)(\_\_\_)+(\_\_\_)^2\)

\(9x^2âˆ’24x+16\)

4

\((5x + \_\_\_)^2\)

\((\_\_\_\;x)^2+2(\_\_\_\;x)(\_\_\_)+(\_\_\_)^2\)

\(25x^2+30x + \_\_\_\)

5

\((kx+m)^2\)

\((\_\_\_\;x)^2+2(\_\_\_\;x)(\_\_\_)+(\_\_\_)^2\)

\((\_\_\_)^2x^2+ \_\_\_\;x+ (\_\_\_)^2\)

  1. Enter the missing values from row 3.

3

\((3x-4)^2\)

\((3x)^2+2(\_\_\_\;x)(\_\_\_)+(\_\_\_)^2\) \((3x)^2+2(\;\underline{\;\mathbf a\boldsymbol.\;}\;x)(\underline{\;\mathbf b\boldsymbol.\;})+(\underline{\;\mathbf c\boldsymbol.\;})^2\)

\(9x^2âˆ’24x+16\)

  1. What is the missing value of a?

Enter the missing value of a.

Correct! 3

The correct answer is 3.


  1. What is the missing value of b?

Enter the missing value of b.

Correct! -4

The correct answer is -4.


  1. What is the missing value of c?

Enter the missing value of c.

Correct! -4

The correct answer is -4.


  1. Enter the missing values from row 4.

4

\((5x + \_\_\_)^2\)
\((5x + \underline{\;\mathbf a\boldsymbol.\;})^2\)

\((\_\_\_\;x)^2+2(\_\_\_\;x)(\_\_\_)+(\_\_\_)^2\)
\((\underline{\;\mathbf b\boldsymbol.\;}\;x)^2+2(\underline{\;\mathbf c\boldsymbol.\;}\;x)(\underline{\;\mathbf d\boldsymbol.\;})+(\underline{\;\mathbf e\boldsymbol.\;})^2\)

\(25x^2+30x + \_\_\_ \)
\(25x^2+30x + \underline{\;\mathbf f\boldsymbol.\;}\)

  1. What is the missing value of a?

Enter the missing value of a.

Correct! 3

The correct answer is 3.


  1. What is the missing value of b?

Enter the missing value of b.

Correct! 5

The correct answer is 5.


  1. What is the missing value of c?

Enter the missing value of c.

Correct! 5

The correct answer is 5.


  1. What is the missing value of d?

Enter the missing value of d.

Correct! 3

The correct answer is 3.


  1. What is the missing value of e?

Enter the missing value of e.

Correct! 3

The correct answer is 3.


  1. What is the missing value of f?

Enter the missing value of f.

Correct! 9

The correct answer is 9.


  1. Enter the missing values from row 5.

5

\((kx+m)^2\)

\((\_\_\_\;x)^2+2(\_\_\_\;x)(\_\_\_)+(\_\_\_)^2\)
\((\underline{\;\mathbf a\boldsymbol.\;}\;x)^2+2(\underline{\;\mathbf b\boldsymbol.\;}\;x)(\underline{\;\mathbf c\boldsymbol.\;})+(\underline{\;\mathbf d\boldsymbol.\;})^2\)

\((\_\_\_)^2x^2 + \_\_\_\;x + (\_\_\_)^2\)
\((\underline{\;\mathbf e\boldsymbol.\;})^2x^2 + \underline{\;\mathbf f\boldsymbol.\;} x + (\underline{\;\mathbf g\boldsymbol.\;} )^2\)

  1. What is the missing value of a?

Enter the missing value of a.

Correct! \(k\)

The correct answer is \(k\).


  1. What is the missing value of b?

Enter the missing value of b.

Correct! \(k\)

The correct answer is \(k\).


  1. What is the missing value of c?

Enter the missing value of c.

Correct! \(m\)

The correct answer is \(m\).


  1. What is the missing value of d?

Enter the missing value of d.

Correct! \(m\)

The correct answer is \(m\).


  1. What is the missing value of e?

Enter the missing value of e.

Correct! \(k\)

The correct answer is \(k\).


  1. What is the missing value of f?

Enter the missing value of f.

Correct! \(2km\)

The correct answer is \(2km\).


  1. What is the missing value of g?

Enter the missing value of g.

Correct! \(m\)

The correct answer is \(m\).


  1. Look at the expression in the last row of the table. If \(ax^2+bx+c\) is equivalent to \((kx+m)^2\), how are \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\) related to \(k\) and \(m\)?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(a=k^2\), \(b=2km\), and \(c=m^2\)

page.title: 9.8.3: Converting from Standard Form to Vertex Form
page.contents:
Activity

You've expanded from factored form to standard form. To learn how to convert from standard form to vertex form (of a quadratic expression), start by going backward and convert a quadratic from vertex form to standard form.


  1. Rewrite \((x+5)^2+1\) in standard form.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x^2+10x+26\)


  1. Rewrite \((xâˆ’3)^2âˆ’7\) in standard form.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x^2âˆ’6x+2\)


  1. Think about the steps you took, and about reversing them. Try converting one or both of the expressions in standard form back into vertex form. Explain how you go about converting the expressions.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

To convert \(x^2âˆ’6x+2\) back to vertex form, you can complete the square by adding 9 and then subtracting 9 so that the expression remains unchanged. The part that is a perfect square, \(x^2âˆ’6x+9\), can be written as \((xâˆ’3)^2\), and then there is the \(2âˆ’9\), which equals -7.


  1. Test your strategy by rewriting \(x^2+10x+9\) in vertex form.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\((x+5)^2âˆ’16\)


  1. Let's check the expression you rewrote in vertex form. Use the Desmos graphing tool or technology outside the course to graph both \(x^2+10x+9\) and your new expression.


  1. Does it appear that both expressions define the same function?

Correct! Yes, both expressions seem to produce the same graph.

The correct answer is Yes.Both expressions seem to produce the same graph.


  1. If you convert your expression in vertex form back into standard form, do you get \(x^2+10x+9\)?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\((x+5)^2âˆ’16=x^2+10x+25âˆ’16\), which is \(x^2+10x+9\).

page.title: 9.8.3: Self Check
page.contents: Which of the following is the equivalent vertex form of the expression \(x^2+14x-3\)?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: This is only the factored perfect square trinomial. The answer is \((x+7)^2-52\).
Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: When the 49 is added to complete the square, it must also be subtracted to balance the expression. The answer is \((x+7)^2-52\).
That's correct! Check yourself: Complete the square with 49, and then subtract 49 from -3. Factor the trinomial and simplify.
Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: Since 49 was added to complete the square, it must be subtracted from -3 to balance the expression. The answer is \((x+7)^2-52\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 9.8.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Standard to Vertex Form

Different forms are useful for finding different characteristics of quadratic functions.

Practice writing \(x^2+8x-7\) into vertex form (of a quadratic expression).

Step 1
Work to complete the square:
\(b=8\), so \((\frac{b}{2})^2=(\frac{8}{2})^2=16\).

Step 2
Add the value to create the perfect square, and subtract the value from the original constant (this is like adding 0).
\(x^2+8x+16-7-16\)

Step 3
Factor the trinomial and simplify.
\((x+4)^2-23\)

Try It: Standard to Vertex Form

Convert the quadratic expression \(x^2+16x-10\) to vertex form.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to write the quadratic expression in vertex form:

Step 1
Work to complete the square:
\(b=16\), so \((\frac{b}{2})^2=(\frac{16}{2})^2=64\).

Step 2
Add the value to create the perfect square, and subtract the value from the original constant (this is like adding 0).
\(x^2+16x+64-10-64\)

Step 3
Factor the trinomial and simplify.
\((x+8)^2-74\)

answer.answer_text: Iâ€™d like to retry the self check.
Iâ€™m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 9.8.4: Rewriting Expressions in Vertex Form
page.contents:
Activity

  1. Here is one way to rewrite \(3x^2+12x+9\) in vertex form (of a quadratic expression).
  1. Study the steps and write a brief explanation of what is happening at each step.

Original expression
\(3x^2+12x+9\)

Step 1
\(3(x^2+4x+3)\)

Step 2
\(3(x^2+4x+4+3âˆ’4)\)

Step 3
\(3(x^2+4x+4âˆ’1)\)

Step 4
\(3((x+2)^2âˆ’1)\)

Step 5
\(3(x+2)^2âˆ’3\)

Write down your answers, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answers:

Original expression
\(3x^2+12x+9\)

Step 1
Rewrite the expression with 3 as a factor.
\(3(x^2+4x+3)\)

Step 2
Add 4 to complete the square.
Subtract 4 to keep the value of the expression the same.
\(3(x^2+4x+4+3âˆ’4)\)

Step 3
Combine like terms so we can see the perfect square, \(x^2+4x+4\).
\(3(x^2+4x+4âˆ’1)\)

Step 4
Rewrite \(x^2+4x+4\) as a squared expression.
\(3((x+2)^2âˆ’1)\)

Step 5
Apply the distributive property to put the expression in vertex form.
\(3(x+2)^2âˆ’3\)


  1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex (of a graph) that represents this expression?

Enter the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex.

Correct! The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex is -2.

The correct answer is -2. The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex is -2.


  1. What is the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of the graph that represents this expression?

Enter the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex.

Correct! The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex is -3.

The correct answer is -3. The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex is -3.


  1. Does the graph open upward or downward? Explain how you know.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

The graph opens upward. For example, in an earlier unit, we saw that when the coefficient of the squared term \((xâˆ’h)^2\) is positive, the graph opens upward.


  1. Rewrite \(-2x^2âˆ’4x+6\) in vertex form.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(-2(x+1)^2+8\)


  1. Rewrite \(4x^2+24x+20\) in vertex form.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(4(x+3)^2âˆ’16\)


  1. Rewrite \(-x^2+20x\) in vertex form.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(-(xâˆ’10)^2+100\)


Extending Your Thinking

  1. Fill in the missing parts of the function \(f(x)=2(xâˆ’3)(xâˆ’9)\) in vertex form \(f(x)= \underline{\;\mathbf a\boldsymbol.\;} (x \underline{\;\mathbf b\boldsymbol.\;} \; \underline{\;\mathbf c\boldsymbol.\;} )^2 \underline{\;\mathbf d\boldsymbol.\;}\; \underline{\;\mathbf e\boldsymbol.\;} \) without completing the square. (Hint: Think about finding the zeros of the function.)
  1. What is the value of the missing number at a?

Enter the value of a.

Compare your answer:

2

  1. What mathematical operation (sign) is missing at b?

Enter the value of b.

Compare your answer:

Minus sign (-)

  1. What is the value of the missing number at c?

Enter the value of c.

Compare your answer:

6

  1. What mathematical operation (sign) is missing at d?

Enter the value of d.

Compare your answer:

Minus sign (-)

  1. What is the value of the missing number at e?

Enter the value of e.

Compare your answer:

18

  1. Explain your reasoning for your answers.

Enter your explanation.

Compare your answer:

The zeros of \(f\) are 3 and 9. Because the graph of a quadratic function has a vertical line of symmetry across the vertex, the vertex of the graph must have \(x\)-coordinate 6. The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex is -18 because \(f(6)=-18\). This means \(f(x)\) can be expressed as \(a(xâˆ’6)^2âˆ’18\). If we expand \(2(xâˆ’3)(xâˆ’9)\), we can see that the coefficient of \(x^2\) is 2. This means that \(a\) in the vertex form has to be 2 as well.

  1. Fill in the missing parts of the function \(g(x)=2(xâˆ’3)(xâˆ’9)+21\) in vertex form \(g(x)= \underline{\;\mathbf a\boldsymbol.\;} (x \underline{\;\mathbf b\boldsymbol.\;} \;\underline{\;\mathbf c\boldsymbol.\;} )^2 \underline{\;\mathbf d\boldsymbol.\;} \;\underline{\;\mathbf e\boldsymbol.\;}\) without completing the square.
  1. What is the value of the missing number at a?

Enter the value of a.

Compare your answer:

2

  1. What mathematical operation (sign) is missing at b?

Enter the value of b.

Compare your answer:

Minus sign (-)

  1. What is the value of the missing number at c?

Enter the value of c.

Compare your answer:

6

  1. What mathematical operation (sign) is missing at d?

Enter the value of d.

Compare your answer:

Addition sign (+)

  1. What is the value of the missing number at e?

Enter the value of e.

Compare your answer:

3

  1. Explain your reasoning for your answers.

Enter your explanation.

Compare your answer:

Although 3 and 9 are not zeros of \(g\), when \(x\) is 3 and when \(x\) is 9, \(g(x)\) is 21, or \(g(3)=g(9)=21\). Because the graphs of quadratic functions are symmetric, the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex is still 6. The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex is 3 because \(g(6)=3\). The value of \(a\) is 2 for the same reason as in function \(f\).

Video: Rewriting Expressions in Vertex Form

Watch the following video to learn more about rewriting expressions in vertex form.

page.title: 9.8.4: Self Check
page.contents: Write \(2x^2+20x+20\) in vertex form.

answer.response: Incorrect. Letâ€™s try again a different way: The constant needs to be included in the process. The correct answer is \(2(x+5)^2-30\).

Thatâ€™s correct! Check yourself: First factor out the 2. Then complete the square and add in 25 while subtracting to balance the expression. This becomes \(2(x^2+10x+25+10-25)\). Then factor and simplify.
Incorrect. Letâ€™s try again a different way: This is factored, but not vertex form. The correct answer is \(2(x+5)^2-30\).
Incorrect. Letâ€™s try again a different way: The 2 has to be distributed to the -15. The correct answer is \(2(x+5)^2-30\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 9.8.4: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Vertex Form with a Leading Coefficient Besides 1

Write \(2x^2+8x+4\) in vertex form (of a quadratic expression).

Original expression
\(2x^2+8x+4\)

Step 1
Rewrite the expression with 2 as a factor.
\(2(x^2+4x+2)\)

Step 2
Add 4 to complete the square.
Subtract 4 to keep the value of the expression the same.
\(2(x^2+4x+4+2âˆ’4)\)

Step 3
Combine like terms so we can see the perfect square, \(x^2+4x+4\).
\(2(x^2+4x+4âˆ’2)\)

Step 4
Rewrite \(x^2+4x+4\) as a squared expression.
\(2((x+2)^2âˆ’2)\)

Step 5
Apply the distributive property to put the expression in vertex form.
\(2(x+2)^2âˆ’4\)

Try It: Vertex Form with a Leading Coefficient Besides 1

Write \(4x^2+24x+12\) in vertex form.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to write the quadratic expression in vertex form:

Original expression
\(4x^2+24x+12\)

Step 1
Rewrite the expression with 4 as a factor.
\(4(x^2+6x+3)\)

Step 2
Add 9 to complete the square.
Subtract 9 to keep the value of the expression the same.
\(4(x^2+6x+9+3âˆ’9)\)

Step 3
Combine like terms so we can see the perfect square, \(x^2+6x+9\).
\(4(x^2+6x+9âˆ’6)\)

Step 4
Rewrite \(x^2+6x+9\) as a squared expression.
\(4((x+3)^2âˆ’6)\)

Step 5
Apply the distributive property to put the expression in vertex form.
\(4(x+3)^2âˆ’24\)

answer.answer_text: Iâ€™d like to retry the self check.
Iâ€™m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 9.8.5: Different Forms of Quadratic Expressions
page.contents:
Optional Activity

Your teacher will give you either a problem card or a data card. Do not show or read your card to your partner.

If your teacher gives you the data card:

  1. Silently read the information on your card.
  2. Ask your partner, "What specific information do you need?" and wait for your partner to ask for information. Only give information that is on your card. (Do not figure out anything for your partner!)
  3. Before telling your partner the information, ask, "Why do you need to know (that piece of information)?"
  4. Read the problem card and solve the problem independently.
  5. Share the data card and discuss your reasoning.

If your teacher gives you the problem card:

  1. Silently read your card and think about what information you need to answer the question.
  2. Ask your partner for the specific information that you need.
  3. Explain to your partner how you are using the information to solve the problem.
  4. When you have enough information, share the problem card with your partner, and solve the problem independently.
  5. Read the data card and discuss your reasoning.

Pause here so your teacher can review your work. Ask your teacher for a new set of cards and repeat the activity, trading roles with your partner.

  1. Use the information about functions \(f\) and \(g\) to answer the questions.
  • Function \(f\) is defined by \((x+3)(x+9)\).
  • Function \(g\) is defined by \((x+6)^2-1\).
  1. Write an expression in vertex form (of a quadratic expression) that could define a quadratic function, \(f\).

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\((x+6)^2âˆ’9\)


  1. Write an expression in factored form that could define a quadratic function, \(g\).

Enter an expression in factored form.

Compare your answer:

\((x+7)(x+5)\)


  1. Show that \(f\) and \(g\) do not define the same function.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Rewriting \(g\) in standard form gives \(x^2+12x+35\), but \(f\) is \(x^2+12x+27\).


----------------------------------------
  1. Functions \(a\) and \(b\) are quadratic functions.
  • Function \(a\) is defined by \((x-5)^2-4\).
  • Function \(b\) is defined by \((x+1)(x-5)\).
  1. What are the zeros of function \(a\)? Select two.

Correct! The zeros of \(a\) are \(x = 3\) and \(x = 7\).

The correct answers are: \(x = 3\) and \(x = 7\). The zeros of \(a\) are \(x = 3\) and \(x = 7\).

------------------------------------

  1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex (of a graph) representing function \(b\)?

Enter the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex.

Correct! The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex is 2.

The correct answer is 2. The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex is 2.


  1. What is the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of the graph representing function \(b\)?

Enter the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex.

Correct! The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex is -9.

The correct answer is -9. The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex is -9.


  1. Show that \(a\) and \(b\) do not define the same function.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Rewriting \(a\) in standard form gives \(x^2âˆ’10x+21\), and \(b\) in standard form is \(x^2âˆ’4xâˆ’5\).

page.title: 9.8.6: Vertex Form and Coordinates of the Vertex
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

A quadratic function is defined by the expression \(x^2âˆ’20x+19\).

Rewrite the expression in vertex form (of a quadratic expression) and give the coordinates of the vertex (of a graph). Show your reasoning.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\((xâˆ’10)^2âˆ’81\). The vertex is at \((10, -81)\).

\(x^2âˆ’20x+19\)
\(x^2âˆ’20x+100+19âˆ’100\)
\(x^2âˆ’20x+100âˆ’81\)
\((xâˆ’10)^2âˆ’81\)

page.title: 9.8.7: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. The following quadratic expressions all define the same function.
  • \((x+5)(x+3)\)
  • \(x^2+8x+15\)
  • \((x+4)^2âˆ’1\)

Select three statements that are true about the graph of this function.

Correct! The vertex is \((-4,-1)\), the \(x\)-intercepts are \((-5,0)\) and \((-3,0)\), the \(y\)-intercept is \((0,15)\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.8.1. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: The vertex is \((-4,-1)\), the \(x\)-intercepts are \((-5,0)\) and \((-3,0)\), the \(y\)-intercept is \((0,15)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The following expressions all define the same quadratic function.
  • \((xâˆ’4)(x+6)\)
  • \(x^2+2xâˆ’24\)
  • \((x+1)^2âˆ’25\)
  1. What is the value of the \(y\)-coordinate of the \(y\)-intercept \((0, \_\_\_)\) of the graph of the function?

Enter the value of the \(y\)-coordinate.

Correct! The \(y\)-intercept is \((0,-24)\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.8.1. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is -24. The \(y\)-intercept is \((0,-24)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Select two \(x\)-intercepts of the graph.

Correct! The \(x\)-intercepts of the graph are \((-6,0)\) and \((4,0)\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.8.1. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: \((-6,0)\), \((4,0)\). The \(x\)-intercepts of the graph are \((-6,0)\) and \((4,0)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What is the \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of the graph?

Enter the \(x\)-coordinate.

Correct! The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of the graph is -1.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.8.1 and 9.8.6. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is -1. The \(x\)-coordinate of the vertex of the graph is -1. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What is the \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of the graph?

Enter the \(y\)-coordinate.

Correct! The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex of the graph is -25.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.8.1 and 9.8.6. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is -25. The \(y\)-coordinate of the vertex graph is -25. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Is this an accurate graph of the function?

Correct! Yes. The \(x\)-intercepts, \(y\)-intercept, and vertex are plotted accurately.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.8.1 and 9.8.6. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Yes. The \(x\)-intercepts, \(y\)-intercept, and vertex are plotted accurately. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Here is one way an expression in standard form is rewritten into vertex form.

Original expression
\(x^2âˆ’7x+6\)

Step 1
\(x^2âˆ’7x+(-\frac{7}{2})^2+6âˆ’(-\frac{7}{2})^2\)

Step 2
\((xâˆ’\frac{7}{2})^2+6âˆ’\frac{49}{4}\)

Step 3
\((xâˆ’\frac{7}{2})^2+\frac{24}{4}âˆ’\frac{49}{4}\)

Step 4
\((xâˆ’\frac{7}{2})^2-\frac{25}{4}\)

  1. In Step 1, where did the number \(-\frac{7}{2}\) come from?

Correct! It is half of -7 being squared.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.8.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: It is half of -7 being squared. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. In Step 1, why was \((-\frac{7}{2})^2\) added and then subtracted?

Correct! It is added to complete the square. It is subtracted to keep the value of the expression unchanged.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.8.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: It is added to complete the square. It is subtracted to keep the value of the expression unchanged. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What happened in Step 2?

Correct! The expression, which is a perfect square, is written as a squared expression.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.8.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: The expression, which is a perfect square, is written as a squared expression. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What happened in Step 3?

Correct! The constant term is written as a fraction so that it has a common denominator, which makes it easier to subtract.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.8.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: The constant term is written as a fraction so that it has a common denominator, which makes it easier to subtract. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What does the last expression tell us about the vertex of the graph of a function defined by this expression?

Correct! The vertex of the graph is at \((\frac{7}{2}, -6\frac{1}{4})\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.8.3 and 9.8.6. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: The vertex of the graph is at \((\frac{7}{2}, -6\frac{1}{4})\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Enter the missing number, including the sign, for the expression when \(d(x)=x^2+12x+36\) is written in vertex form.

\(d(x)=(x\_\_\_)^2\).

Enter the missing number, including the sign.

Correct! +6

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.8.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is +6. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Enter the missing numbers, including the signs, for the expression when \(f(x)=x^2+10x+21\) is written in vertex form. \(f(x)=(x + \underline{\;\mathbf a\boldsymbol.\;})^2 \underline{\;\mathbf b\boldsymbol.\;}\)
  1. What is the value of the missing number, including the sign, in the place of the letter a?

Enter the missing number, including the sign.

Correct! +5

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.8.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is +5. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What is the value of the missing number, including the sign, for the letter b?

Enter the missing number, including the sign.

Correct! -4

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.8.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is -4. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Enter the missing numbers, including the signs, for the expression when \(g(x)=2x^2âˆ’20x+32\) is written in vertex form. \(g(x)= \underline{\;\mathbf a\boldsymbol.\;} (x + \underline{\;\mathbf b\boldsymbol.\;} )^2 \underline{\;\mathbf c\boldsymbol.\;}\)
  1. What is the value of the missing number, including the sign, in place of letter a?

Enter the missing number, including the sign.

Correct! +2

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.8.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is +2. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What is the value of the missing number, including the sign, in place of letter b?

Enter the missing number, including the sign.

Correct! -5

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.8.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is -5. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What is the value of the missing number, including the sign, in place of letter c?

    2. Enter the missing number, including the sign.

Correct! -18

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.8.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is -18. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Enter the missing numbers, including the signs, for the expression when \(h(x)=(4x-3)^2\) is expanded to standard form. \(h(x)= ( \underline{\;\mathbf a\boldsymbol.\;}\; x )^2 + 2 ( \underline{\;\mathbf b\boldsymbol.\;}\; x)(-3) + ( \underline{\;\mathbf c\boldsymbol.\;} )^2\)
  1. What is the value of the missing number, including the sign, in place of letter a?

Enter the missing number, including the sign.

Correct! +4

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.8.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is +4. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What is the value of the missing number, including the sign, in place of letter b?

Enter the missing number, including the sign.

Correct! +4

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.8.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is +4. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What is the value of the missing number, including the sign, in place of letter c?

Enter the missing number, including the sign.

Correct! -3

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.8.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is -3. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 9.8.8: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Identify the vertex of the graph of a quadratic function when the expression that defines it is written in vertex form.
  • Explain the meaning of the term "vertex form" and recognize examples of quadratic expressions written in this form.
  • When given a quadratic expression in factored form, rewrite it in standard form.
  • When given a quadratic expression in standard form, rewrite it in vertex form.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 9.8.1: The Vertex and Intercepts of a Function
    • In this activity, you determined the vertex, the \(x\)-intercepts, and the \(y\)-intercept for three different expressions that represent the same function.
  • 9.8.2: Expanding from Factored Form to Standard Form
    • In this activity, you rewrote expressions that were in factored form into standard form.
  • 9.8.3: Converting from Standard Form to Vertex Form
    • In this activity, you rewrote two expressions that were in vertex form into standard form.
    • 9.8.3: Self Check
    • 9.8.3: Additional Resources
  • 9.8.4: Rewriting Expressions in Vertex Form
    • In this activity, you transformed expressions, whose squared term had a coefficient other than 1, into vertex form.
    • 9.8.4: Self Check
    • 9.8.4: Additional Resources
  • 9.8.5: Different Forms of Quadratic Expressions
    • In this optional activity, you wrote expressions in vertex form and factored form that could define a quadratic function.
  • 9.8.6: Vertex Form and Coordinates of the Vertex
    • In this activity, you wrote an expression in vertex form and found the coordinates of the vertex.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 9.8.7: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If youâ€™ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
